_prev_prog_3.Description: Storage of Chlorine, Hydrofluoric Acid, and Sulfur Dioxide

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The purpose of this document is to inform interested persons, including the public, that our facility is complying with the Environmental Protection Agency Accidental Release and Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs under the Clean Air Act Sections 112(R)(7). This regulation is published in 40 CFR Part 68. We have assessed and continue to review how accidental releases may occur, and how the public and the environment might be impacted. After reading this program, you may consider making recommendations for improvements to the Branch Operations Manager. Vopak, USA is a distributor of industrial chemicals. We store three substances that are regulated by the above cited Act at or above the threshold quantities; chlorine, hydrofluoric acid, and sulfur dioxide. Chlorine is a pungent greenish yellow gas or amber color in liquid form. The material is irritating to the skin and eyes, and is a toxic inhalation hazard. Chlorine is heavier than air and tends to settle in low areas. Chlorine is not flammable, but may support combustion. Hydrofluoric Acid is a colorless corrosive/poisonous liquid. It is a skin, eye, and inhalation hazard. The material is not flammable. Sulfur Dioxide is a colorless corrosive gas or liquid. It is a skin, eye, and inhalation hazard. The material has a pungent odor.
WORST-CASE CHLORINE SCENARIO, ERPG 3_ Based on modeling, a complete failure and release of our largest container (2000 pounds) may impact the surrounding area within 1.3 miles.
ALTERNATE RELEASE CHLORINE SCENARIO, ERPG 3_ Based on modeling, the alternate release of 10 pounds of chlorine may impact the surrounding area within 0.1 miles.
WORST-CASE HYDROFLUORIC ACID SCENARIO, ERPG 3_ Based on modeling, the complete failure and release of our largest container (500 pounds) may impact the surrounding area within 0.3 miles.

WORST-CASE RELEASE SULFUR DIOXIDE SCENARIO, ERPG 3_ Based on modeling, a complete failure and release of our largest container (2000 pounds) may impact the surrounding area within 1.3 miles.
ALTERNATE RELEASE SULFUR DIOXIDE SCENARIO, ERPG 3_ Based on modeling, the alternate release of 10 pounds of material may impact the surrounding area within 0.1 miles
Designing fo Safety: Cylinders and drums are stored in a fenced enclosure; Cylinders are secured in racks to prevent tip-over, and drum materials are wrapped on pallets; Packages are stored away from combustibles; Cylinders and drums must meet the US Department of Transportation requirements for safe packaging.
Maintaining the Plant: All maintenance is performed by qualified bonded contractors; Handling equipment is inspected daily for damage and operability.
Operating Safely: Only trained employees are allowed to operate equipment and handle hazardous materials; Observations are made to insure procedures are followed.
Auditing Operations: Operators inspect containers daily: Loss Control Audits are performed by our insurer; Internal Audits are conducted annually; Regulatory inspections are made by state and federal agencies.
Training and Preparation: Plant Emergency Response Plan; Local Emergency Planning Committee; Emergency equipment is stored on-site; Employees receive continual training; Fire Department Hazardous Materials Response Team.
If a release occurs at our facility: 1. The plant alarm is sounded; 2. The facility coordinator is called to assess the release; 3. Fire department Hazardous Materials Team is called and the facility evacuated; 4. Richmond County Emergency Management Agency is notified; 5. Release is controlled and adequate cleanup and decontamination is performed. We have had no reportable releases in in the last five years.
